newsitem.title: USA: Orange Cty D.A. seeks prison term for treasurer Citron.
newsitem.headline: Orange Cty D.A. seeks prison term for treasurer Citron.

text.p: The former treasurer of California's Orange County should serve seven years in state prison for crimes stemming from the largest municipal bankruptcy in U.S. history, the county district attorney said Tuesday.
In court papers filed in Santa Ana, Orange County District Attorney Michael Capizzi also recommended that former Treasurer Robert Citron be fined $400,000.

In a separate filing, Citron attorney David Wiechert urged the judge to show leniency by sentencing Citron to probation and a fine of $10,000. If any confinement were to be required, Citron should only receive home detention, Wiechert argued.
"A prison term would take away the last vestiges of Mr. Citron's reason for being," Wiechert said.
The court will review these recommendations in preparation for Citron's sentencing hearing, set for Nov. 18.
Citron pleaded guilty last year to several counts of securities fraud and misappropriation of public funds. He faces up to 14 years in prison.
Orange County filed for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 6, 1994, after sustaining losses of more than $1.6 billion on risky investments.
The county emerged from bankruptcy last June.
